div.l: Oure maunciple I hope he wil be deed
Swa warkes him ay the wanges in his heed
And therfore is I come and ek Aleyn
To grynde oure corn and carie it ham agayn
I preye ȝou spedes vs hethen that ȝe may
It shal be don qduod Symkyn by my fay
What wil ȝe don while it is in hande
Certis right by the hoper wil I stande
And se how gates the Corn gas ynne
Ȝitt saw I neuer by my fadir kynne
How that the hoper wagges to and fra
Aleyn answeride Iohn wiltow swa
Thanne wil I be bynethe by my Croune
And se how gates the mele falles adoune
Intyl the trough that shal be my disporte
Quod Iohn in faith I may ben of ȝoure sorte
I is as ille a meller as ere ȝe
This Meller smylide of her nycete
And thought al this is don but for a wyle
They wene that no man may them bigyle
But by my thrift ȝit shal I blere her ye
For al the Slyȝt in her philosophye
The more queynt Clerkis that thei make
The more wil I stele whānne y take
In stede of flour ȝitt wil I ȝeue hem brenne
The grettiste Clerkis ben nought wisest menne
As whilom to the wolf thus spake the mare
Of alle her Art Counte I nought a tare
Out of the dore he goth ful pryuely
Whanne that he saugh his tyme softly
He loketh vp and doıı̄un tyl he hath founde
The Clerkis hors there as he stode ybounde
Byhynde the Mille vndir a leuesil
And to the hors he goth hym faire and wel
He stripeth off the brydill ryght anoon
And whanne the hors was laus he gynneþ gon
